member.name: T:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.ExtensionHelper
member.summary: Extension helpers for working with the AST.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.ExtensionHelper.AsParams``1(System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{``0})
member.summary: Uses a collection as parameters for a method call.
member.param: Same as calling params object[] overload. Instead of specifying each param, ICollection can be used for convenience.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.PropertyHelper.#ctor(System.Reflection.PropertyInfo)
member.summary: Initializes a fast . This constructor does not cache the helper. For caching, use .

member.name: P:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.PropertyHelper.Property
member.summary: Gets the backing .

member.name: P:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.PropertyHelper.Name
member.summary: Gets (or sets in derived types) the property name.

member.name: P:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.PropertyHelper.ValueGetter
member.summary: Gets the property value getter.

member.name: P:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.PropertyHelper.ValueSetter
member.summary: Gets the property value setter.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.PropertyHelper.GetValue(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the property value for the specified .
member.param: The object whose property value will be returned.
member.returns: The property value.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.PropertyHelper.SetValue(System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Sets the property value for the specified .

The property value.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.PropertyHelper.GetProperties(System.Object)
member.summary: Creates and caches fast property helpers that expose getters for every public get property on the underlying type.
member.param: the instance to extract property accessors for.
member.returns: a cached array of all public property getters from the underlying type of target instance.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.PropertyHelper.GetProperties(System.Type)
member.summary: Creates and caches fast property helpers that expose getters for every public get property on the specified type.
member.param: the type to extract property accessors for.
member.returns: a cached array of all public property getters from the type of target instance.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.PropertyHelper.GetVisibleProperties(System.Object)

summary.para: Creates and caches fast property helpers that expose getters for every non-hidden get property on the specified type.
excludes properties defined on base types that have been hidden by definitions using the new keyword.

member.param: The instance to extract property accessors for.
member.returns: A cached array of all public property getters from the instance's type.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.PropertyHelper.GetVisibleProperties(System.Type)

summary.para: Creates a caches fast property helpers that expose getters for every non-hidden get property on the specified type.
excludes properties defined on base types that have been hidden by definitions using the new keyword.

member.param: The type to extract property accessors for.
member.returns: A cached array of all public property getters from the type.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.PropertyHelper.MakeFastPropertyGetter(System.Reflection.PropertyInfo)
member.summary: Creates a single fast property getter. The result is not cached.
member.param: propertyInfo to extract the getter for.
member.returns: a fast getter.
member.remarks: This method is more memory efficient than a dynamically compiled lambda, and about the same speed.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.PropertyHelper.MakeNullSafeFastPropertyGetter(System.Reflection.PropertyInfo)
member.summary: Creates a single fast property getter which is safe for a null input object. The result is not cached.
member.param: propertyInfo to extract the getter for.
member.returns: a fast getter.
member.remarks: This method is more memory efficient than a dynamically compiled lambda, and about the same speed.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.PropertyHelper.MakeFastPropertySetter(System.Reflection.PropertyInfo)
member.summary: Creates a single fast property setter for reference types. The result is not cached.
member.param: propertyInfo to extract the setter for.
member.returns: a fast getter.
member.remarks: This method is more memory efficient than a dynamically compiled lambda, and about the same speed. This only works for reference types.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.PropertyHelper.ObjectToDictionary(System.Object)
member.summary:
Given an object, adds each instance property with a public get method as a key and its associated value to a dictionary.
If the object is already an IDictionary{string,object} instance, then a copy is returned.
member.remarks: The implementation of PropertyHelper will cache the property accessors per-type. This is faster when the the same type is used multiple times with ObjectToDictionary.

member.summary: DO NOT USE DIRECTLY

member.name: T:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.ReqlAst
member.summary: Base class for all reql queries.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.ReqlAst.RunAsync``1(RethinkDb.Driver.Net.IConnection,System.Object,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Runs the query on the connection. If you know the response type of your query, T (SUCCESS_ATOM) or Cursor[T] (SUCCESS_SEQUENCE or SUCCESS_PARTIAL) it's recommended to use `.RunAtom`, `.RunCursor` or `.RunResult` helpers as they offer a slight edge in performance since both bypass the dynamic language runtime execution engine.
member.returns: Returns T or Cursor[T]

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.ReqlAst.RunAsync``1(RethinkDb.Driver.Net.IConnection,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Runs the query on the connection. member.returns: Returns T or Cursor[T]

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.ReqlAst.RunNoReply(RethinkDb.Driver.Net.IConnection,System.Object)
member.summary: Executes a query with no expected response. Useful for fire-and-forget queries like insert, update.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.ReqlAst.RunCursorAsync``1(RethinkDb.Driver.Net.IConnection,System.Object,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Use this method if you're expecting a cursor (SUCCESS_SEQUENCE or SUCCESS_PARTIAL) response from your query. This method offers a slight edge in performance without the need for the dynamic language runtime like the run() method uses.
member.param: connection
global anonymous type optional arguments
Cancellation token used to stop *waiting* for a query response. The cancellation token does not cancel the query's execution on the server.
member.returns: A Cursor

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.ReqlAst.RunResultAsync``1(RethinkDb.Driver.Net.IConnection,System.Object,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Use this method if you're expecting SUCCESS_ATOM or SUCCESS_SEQUENCE response from your query. This method offers a slight edge in performance without the need for the dynamic language runtime like the run() method uses. Consider using RunAtom or RunCursor if your response is either SUCCESS_ATOM or SUCCESS_SEQUENCE respectively. Exercise caution using this method with large datasets as the server can switch responses from SUCESS_SEQUENCE to SUCCESS_PARTIAL for the same exact query. Refer to the online documentation for this run helper.
member.param: connection
global anonymous type optional arguments
Cancellation token used to stop *waiting* for a query response. The cancellation token does not cancel the query's execution on the server.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.ReqlAst.RunResultAsync``1(RethinkDb.Driver.Net.IConnection,System.Threading.CancellationToken)

This method offers a slight edge in performance without the need for the dynamic language runtime like the run() method uses. Consider using RunAtom or RunCursor if your response is either SUCCESS_ATOM or SUCCESS_SEQUENCE respectively. Exercise caution using this method with large datasets as the server can switch responses from SUCESS_SEQUENCE to SUCCESS_PARTIAL for the same exact query. Refer to the online documentation for this run helper.
member.param: connection
Cancellation token used to stop *waiting* for a query response. The cancellation token does not cancel the query's execution on the server.

member.name: P:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.ReqlExpr.Item(System.String)
member.summary: Get a single field from an object. If called on a sequence, gets that field from every object in the sequence, skipping objects that lack it.

member.name: P:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.ReqlExpr.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the nth element of a sequence, counting from zero. If the argument is negative, count from the last element.

summary.para: Test if two or more values are equal.

example.para: Example: See if a user's role field is set to administrator.

summary.para: Test if two or more values are not equal.

example.para: Example: See if a user's role field is not set to administrator.

summary.para: Compare values, testing if the left-hand value is less than the right-hand.

example.para: Example: Test if a player has scored less than 10 points.

summary.para: Compare values, testing if the left-hand value is less than or equal to the right-hand.

example.para: Example: Test if a player has scored 10 points or less.

summary.para: Compare values, testing if the left-hand value is greater than the right-hand.

example.para: Example: Test if a player has scored more than 10 points.

summary.para: Compare values, testing if the left-hand value is greater than or equal to the right-hand.

example.para: Example: Test if a player has scored 10 points or more.

summary.para: Compute the logical inverse (not) of an expression.

example.para: Example: Not true is false.
These evaluate to false.

summary.para: Sum two or more numbers, or concatenate two or more strings or arrays.

example.para: Example: It's as easy as 2 + 2 = 4.

summary.para: Subtract two numbers.

example.para: Example: It's as easy as 2 - 2 = 0.

summary.para: Multiply two numbers, or make a periodic array.

example.para: Example: It's as easy as 2 * 2 = 4.

summary.para: Divide two numbers.

example.para: Example: It's as easy as 2 / 2 = 1.
Example: It's as easy as 2 % 2 = 0.

summary.para: Rounds the given value down, returning the largest integer value less than or equal to the given value (the value's floor).

example.para: Example: Return the floor of 12.345.
The floor command can also be chained after an expression.

summary.para: Rounds the given value up, returning the smallest integer value greater than or equal to the given value (the value's ceiling).

example.para: Example: Return the ceiling of 12.345.
The ceil command can also be chained after an expression.

summary.para: Rounds the given value to the nearest whole integer.

example.para: Example: Round 12.345 to the nearest integer.
The round command can also be chained after an expression.

summary.para: Append a value to an array.

example.para: Example: Retrieve Iron Man's equipment list with the addition of some new boots.

summary.para: Prepend a value to an array.

example.para: Example: Retrieve Iron Man's equipment list with the addition of some new boots.

summary.para: Remove the elements of one array from another array.

example.para: Example: Retrieve Iron Man's equipment list without boots.

summary.para: Add a value to an array and return it as a set (an array with distinct values).

example.para: Example: Retrieve Iron Man's equipment list with the addition of some new boots.

summary.para: Intersect two arrays returning values that occur in both of them as a set (an array with distinct values).

example.para: Example: Check which pieces of equipment Iron Man has from a fixed list.

summary.para: Add a several values to an array and return it as a set (an array with distinct values).

example.para: Example: Retrieve Iron Man's equipment list with the addition of some new boots and an arc reactor.

summary.para: Remove the elements of one array from another and return them as a set (an array with distinct values).

example.para: Example: Check which pieces of equipment Iron Man has, excluding a fixed list.

summary.para: Return the elements of a sequence within the specified range.

example.para: Example: Return the fourth, fifth and sixth youngest players. (The youngest player is at index 0, so those are elements 3-5.)

summary.para: Return the elements of a sequence within the specified range.

example.para: Example: Return the fourth, fifth and sixth youngest players. (The youngest player is at index 0, so those are elements 3-5.)

summary.para: Skip a number of elements from the head of the sequence.

example.para: Example: Here in conjunction with orderBy we choose to ignore the most successful heroes.

summary.para: End the sequence after the given number of elements.

example.para: Example: Only so many can fit in our Pantheon of heroes.

summary.para: Get the indexes of an element in a sequence. If the argument is a predicate, get the indexes of all elements matching it.

example.para: Example: Find the position of the letter 'c'.

summary.para: Get the indexes of an element in a sequence. If the argument is a predicate, get the indexes of all elements matching it.

example.para: Example: Find the position of the letter 'c'.

summary.para: Get the indexes of an element in a sequence. If the argument is a predicate, get the indexes of all elements matching it.

example.para: Example: Find the position of the letter 'c'.

summary.para: When called with values, returns true if a sequence contains all the specified values. When called with predicate functions, returns true if for each predicate there exists at least one element of the stream where that predicate returns true.

example.para: Example: Has Iron Man ever fought Superman?

summary.para: Get a single field from an object. If called on a sequence, gets that field from every object in the sequence, skipping objects that lack it.

example.para: Example: What was Iron Man's first appearance in a comic?

summary.para: Get a single field from an object. If called on a sequence, gets that field from every object in the sequence, skipping objects that lack it.

example.para: Example: What was Iron Man's first appearance in a comic?

summary.para: Return an array containing all of an object's keys. Note that the keys will be sorted as described in ReQL data types (for strings, lexicographically).

example.para: Example: Get all the keys from a table row.

summary.para: Test if an object has one or more fields. An object has a field if it has that key and the key has a non-null value. For instance, the object {'a': 1,'b': 2,'c': null} has the fields a and b.

example.para: Example: Return the players who have won games.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.ReqlExpr.HasFields(System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{System.String})

summary.para: Test if an object has one or more fields. An object has a field if it has that key and the key has a non-null value. For instance, the object {'a': 1,'b': 2,'c': null} has the fields a and b.

example.para: Example: Return the players who have won games.

member.param: Same as calling params object[] overload, except the collection is applied as object[] params.

summary.para: Plucks one or more attributes from a sequence of objects, filtering out any objects in the sequence that do not have the specified fields. Functionally, this is identical to hasFields followed by pluck on a sequence.

example.para: Example: Get a list of users and their posts, excluding any users who have not made any posts.
Existing table structure:
Command and output:

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.ReqlExpr.WithFields(System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{System.String})

summary.para: Plucks one or more attributes from a sequence of objects, filtering out any objects in the sequence that do not have the specified fields. Functionally, this is identical to hasFields followed by pluck on a sequence.

example.para: Example: Get a list of users and their posts, excluding any users who have not made any posts.

Command and output:

member.param: Same as calling params object[] overload, except the collection is applied as object[] params.

summary.para: Plucks out one or more attributes from either an object or a sequence of objects (projection).

example.para: Example: We just need information about IronMan's reactor and not the rest of the document.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.ReqlExpr.Pluck(System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{System.String})

summary.para: Plucks out one or more attributes from either an object or a sequence of objects (projection).

example.para: Example: We just need information about IronMan's reactor and not the rest of the document.

member.param: Same as calling params object[] overload, except the collection is applied as object[] params.

summary.para: The opposite of pluck; takes an object or a sequence of objects, and returns them with the specified paths removed.

example.para: Example: Since we don't need it for this computation we'll save bandwidth and leave out the list of IronMan's romantic conquests.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Ast.ReqlExpr.Without(System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{System.String})

summary.para: The opposite of pluck; takes an object or a sequence of objects, and returns them with the specified paths removed.

example.para: Example: Since we don't need it for this computation we'll save bandwidth and leave out the list of IronMan's romantic conquests.

member.param: Same as calling params object[] overload, except the collection is applied as object[] params.

summary.para: Merge two or more objects together to construct a new object with properties from all. When there is a conflict between field names, preference is given to fields in the rightmost object in the argument list. merge also accepts a subquery function that returns an object, which will be used similarly to a map function.

example.para: Example: Equip Thor for battle.

summary.para: Get all documents between two keys. Accepts three optional arguments: index, leftBound, and rightBound. If index is set to the name of a secondary index, between will return all documents where that index's value is in the specified range (it uses the primary key by default). leftBound or rightBound may be set to open or closed to indicate whether or not to include that endpoint of the range (by default, leftBound is closed and rightBound is open).

example.para: Example: Find all users with primary key >= 10 and < 20 (a normal half-open interval).

summary.para: Produce a single value from a sequence through repeated application of a reduction function.

example.para: Example: Return the number of documents in the table posts.
A shorter way to execute this query is to use count.

summary.para: Produce a single value from a sequence through repeated application of a reduction function.

example.para: Example: Return the number of documents in the table posts.
A shorter way to execute this query is to use count.

summary.para: Apply a function to a sequence in order, maintaining state via an accumulator. The fold command returns either a single value or a new sequence.

example.para: Example: Concatenate words from a list.
(This example could be implemented with reduce, but fold will preserve the order when words is a RethinkDB table or other stream, which is not guaranteed with reduce.)

summary.para: Apply a function to a sequence in order, maintaining state via an accumulator. The fold command returns either a single value or a new sequence.

example.para: Example: Concatenate words from a list.
(This example could be implemented with reduce, but fold will preserve the order when words is a RethinkDB table or other stream, which is not guaranteed with reduce.)

summary.para: Transform each element of one or more sequences by applying a mapping function to them. If map is run with two or more sequences, it will iterate for as many items as there are in the shortest sequence.

example.para: Example: Return the first five squares.

summary.para: Transform each element of one or more sequences by applying a mapping function to them. If map is run with two or more sequences, it will iterate for as many items as there are in the shortest sequence.

example.para: Example: Return the first five squares.

summary.para: Removes duplicates from elements in a sequence.

example.para: Example: Which unique villains have been vanquished by Marvel heroes?

summary.para: Counts the number of elements in a sequence or key/value pairs in an object, or returns the size of a string or binary object.

example.para: Example: Count the number of users.

summary.para: Counts the number of elements in a sequence or key/value pairs in an object, or returns the size of a string or binary object.

example.para: Example: Count the number of users.

summary.para: Counts the number of elements in a sequence or key/value pairs in an object, or returns the size of a string or binary object.

example.para: Example: Count the number of users.

summary.para: Counts the number of elements in a sequence or key/value pairs in an object, or returns the size of a string or binary object.

example.para: Example: Count the number of users.

summary.para: Test if a sequence is empty.

example.para: Example: Are there any documents in the marvel table?

summary.para: Merge two or more sequences.

example.para: Example: Construct a stream of all heroes.

summary.para: Get the nth element of a sequence, counting from zero. If the argument is negative, count from the last element.

example.para: Example: Select the second element in the array.

summary.para: Get a single field from an object. If called on a sequence, gets that field from every object in the sequence, skipping objects that lack it.

example.para: Example: What was Iron Man's first appearance in a comic?

summary.para: Returns an inner join of two sequences.

example.para: Example: Return a list of all matchups between Marvel and DC heroes in which the DC hero could beat the Marvel hero in a fight.

summary.para: Returns an inner join of two sequences.

example.para: Example: Return a list of all matchups between Marvel and DC heroes in which the DC hero could beat the Marvel hero in a fight.

summary.para: Returns a left outer join of two sequences. The returned sequence represents a union of the left-hand sequence and the right-hand sequence: all documents in the left-hand sequence will be returned, each matched with a document in the right-hand sequence if one satisfies the predicate condition. In most cases, you will want to follow the join with zip to combine the left and right results.

example.para: Example: Return a list of all Marvel heroes, paired with any DC heroes who could beat them in a fight.
(Compare this to an innerJoin with the same inputs and predicate, which would return a list only of the matchups in which the DC hero has the higher strength.)

summary.para: Returns a left outer join of two sequences. The returned sequence represents a union of the left-hand sequence and the right-hand sequence: all documents in the left-hand sequence will be returned, each matched with a document in the right-hand sequence if one satisfies the predicate condition. In most cases, you will want to follow the join with zip to combine the left and right results.

example.para: Example: Return a list of all Marvel heroes, paired with any DC heroes who could beat them in a fight.
(Compare this to an innerJoin with the same inputs and predicate, which would return a list only of the matchups in which the DC hero has the higher strength.)

summary.para: Join tables using a field or function on the left-hand sequence matching primary keys or secondary indexes on the right-hand table. eqJoin is more efficient than other ReQL join types, and operates much faster. Documents in the result set consist of pairs of left-hand and right-hand documents, matched when the field on the left-hand side exists and is non-null and an entry with that field's value exists in the specified index on the right-hand side.

Join tables using a field or function on the left-hand sequence matching primary keys or secondary indexes on the right-hand table. eqJoin is more efficient than other ReQL join types, and operates much faster. Documents in the result set consist of pairs of left-hand and right-hand documents, matched when the field on the left-hand side exists and is non-null and an entry with that field's value exists in the specified index on the right-hand side.

Join tables using a field or function on the left-hand sequence matching primary keys or secondary indexes on the right-hand table. eqJoin is more efficient than other ReQL join types, and operates much faster. Documents in the result set consist of pairs of left-hand and right-hand documents, matched when the field on the left-hand side exists and is non-null and an entry with that field's value exists in the specified index on the right-hand side.
Used to 'zip' up the result of a join by merging the 'right' fields into 'left' fields of each member of the sequence.

example.para: Example: 'zips up' the sequence by merging the left and right fields produced by a join.

summary.para: Insert a value in to an array at a given index. Returns the modified array.

example.para: Example: Hulk decides to join the avengers.

summary.para: Remove one or more elements from an array at a given index. Returns the modified array. (Note: deleteAt operates on arrays, not documents; to delete documents, see the delete command.)

example.para: Example: Delete the second element of an array.

summary.para: Remove one or more elements from an array at a given index. Returns the modified array. (Note: deleteAt operates on arrays, not documents; to delete documents, see the delete command.)

example.para: Example: Delete the second element of an array.

summary.para: Change a value in an array at a given index. Returns the modified array.

example.para: Example: Bruce Banner hulks out.

summary.para: Insert several values in to an array at a given index. Returns the modified array.

example.para: Example: Hulk and Thor decide to join the avengers.

summary.para: Convert a value of one type into another.

example.para: Example: Coerce a stream to an array to store its output in a field. (A stream cannot be stored in a field directly.)

summary.para: Gets the type of a ReQL query's return value.

example.para: Example: Get the type of a string.

summary.para: Update JSON documents in a table. Accepts a JSON document, a ReQL expression, or a combination of the two.

example.para: Example: Update the status of the post with id of 1 to published.

summary.para: Update JSON documents in a table. Accepts a JSON document, a ReQL expression, or a combination of the two.

example.para: Example: Update the status of the post with id of 1 to published.

summary.para: Update JSON documents in a table. Accepts a JSON document, a ReQL expression, or a combination of the two.

example.para: Example: Update the status of the post with id of 1 to published.

summary.para: Delete one or more documents from a table.

example.para: Example: Delete a single document from the table comments.

summary.para: Replace documents in a table. Accepts a JSON document or a ReQL expression, and replaces the original document with the new one. The new document must have the same primary key as the original document.

example.para: Example: Replace the document with the primary key 1.

summary.para: Replace documents in a table. Accepts a JSON document or a ReQL expression, and replaces the original document with the new one. The new document must have the same primary key as the original document.

example.para: Example: Replace the document with the primary key 1.

summary.para: Replace documents in a table. Accepts a JSON document or a ReQL expression, and replaces the original document with the new one. The new document must have the same primary key as the original document.

example.para: Example: Replace the document with the primary key 1.

summary.para: Compute the logical "or" of one or more values.

example.para: Example: Return whether either a or b evaluate to true.

summary.para: Compute the logical "and" of one or more values.

example.para: Example: Return whether both a and b evaluate to true.

summary.para: Loop over a sequence, evaluating the given write query for each element.

example.para: Example: Now that our heroes have defeated their villains, we can safely remove them from the villain table.

summary.para: Get information about a ReQL value.

example.para: Example: Get information about a table such as primary key, or cache size.

summary.para: Matches against a regular expression. If there is a match, returns an object with the fields:

ul.li: str: The matched string
start: The matched string's start
end: The matched string's end
groups: The capture groups defined with parentheses

summary.para: If no match is found, returns null.

example.para: Example: Get all users whose name starts with "A". Because null evaluates to false in filter, you can just use the result of match for the predicate.

Result:
Note: upcase and downcase only affect ASCII characters.

summary.para: Lowercases a string.

example.para: Example:
Result:
Note: upcase and downcase only affect ASCII characters.

summary.para: Select a given number of elements from a sequence with uniform random distribution. Selection is done without replacement.

example.para: Example: Select 3 random heroes.

summary.para: Provide a default value in case of non-existence errors. The default command evaluates its first argument (the value it's chained to). If that argument returns null or a non-existence error is thrown in evaluation, then default returns its second argument. The second argument is usually a default value, but it can be a function that returns a value.

example.para: Example: Retrieve the titles and authors of the table posts. In the case where the author field is missing or null, we want to retrieve the string Anonymous.

summary.para: Provide a default value in case of non-existence errors. The default command evaluates its first argument (the value it's chained to). If that argument returns null or a non-existence error is thrown in evaluation, then default returns its second argument. The second argument is usually a default value, but it can be a function that returns a value.

example.para: Example: Retrieve the titles and authors of the table posts. In the case where the author field is missing or null, we want to retrieve the string Anonymous.

summary.para: Convert a ReQL value or object to a JSON string. You may use either toJsonString or toJSON.

example.para: Example: Get a ReQL document as a JSON string.

summary.para: Convert a ReQL value or object to a JSON string. You may use either toJsonString or toJSON.

example.para: Example: Get a ReQL document as a JSON string.

summary.para: Convert a time object to a string in ISO 8601 format.

example.para: Example: Return the current ISO 8601 time.

summary.para: Convert a time object to its epoch time.

example.para: Example: Return the current time in seconds since the Unix Epoch with millisecond-precision.

summary.para: Return a new time object with a different timezone. While the time stays the same, the results returned by methods such as hours() will change since they take the timezone into account. The timezone argument has to be of the ISO 8601 format.

example.para: Example: Hour of the day in San Francisco (UTC/GMT -8, without daylight saving time).

summary.para: Return whether a time is between two other times.

example.para: Example: Retrieve all the posts that were posted between December 1st, 2013 (inclusive) and December 10th, 2013 (exclusive).

summary.para: Return a new time object only based on the day, month and year (ie. the same day at 00:00).

example.para: Example: Retrieve all the users whose birthday is today.

summary.para: Return the number of seconds elapsed since the beginning of the day stored in the time object.

example.para: Example: Retrieve posts that were submitted before noon.

summary.para: Return the timezone of the time object.

example.para: Example: Return all the users in the "-07:00" timezone.

summary.para: Return the year of a time object.

example.para: Example: Retrieve all the users born in 1986.

summary.para: Return the month of a time object as a number between 1 and 12. For your convenience, the terms r.january, r.february etc. are defined and map to the appropriate integer.

example.para: Example: Retrieve all the users who were born in November.

summary.para: Return the day of a time object as a number between 1 and 31.

example.para: Example: Return the users born on the 24th of any month.

summary.para: Return the day of week of a time object as a number between 1 and 7 (following ISO 8601 standard). For your convenience, the terms r.monday, r.tuesday etc. are defined and map to the appropriate integer.

example.para: Example: Return today's day of week.

summary.para: Return the day of the year of a time object as a number between 1 and 366 (following ISO 8601 standard).

example.para: Example: Retrieve all the users who were born the first day of a year.

summary.para: Return the hour in a time object as a number between 0 and 23.

example.para: Example: Return all the posts submitted after midnight and before 4am.

summary.para: Return the minute in a time object as a number between 0 and 59.

example.para: Example: Return all the posts submitted during the first 10 minutes of every hour.

summary.para: Return the seconds in a time object as a number between 0 and 59.999 (double precision).

example.para: Example: Return the post submitted during the first 30 seconds of every minute.

summary.para: Sums all the elements of a sequence. If called with a field name, sums all the values of that field in the sequence, skipping elements of the sequence that lack that field. If called with a function, calls that function on every element of the sequence and sums the results, skipping elements of the sequence where that function returns null or a non-existence error.

example.para: Example: What's 3 + 5 + 7?

example.para: Example: What's the average of 3, 5, and 7?

summary.para: Splits a string into substrings. Splits on whitespace when called with no arguments. When called with a separator, splits on that separator. When called with a separator and a maximum number of splits, splits on that separator at most max_splits times. (Can be called with null as the separator if you want to split on whitespace while still specifying max_splits.)

example.para: Example: Split on whitespace.
Result:

When called with a separator and a maximum number of splits, splits on that separator at most max_splits times. summary.para: Takes a grouped stream or grouped data and turns it into an array of objects representing the groups. Any commands chained after ungroup will operate on this array, rather than operating on each group individually. This is useful if you want to e.g. order the groups by the value of their reduction.

example.para: Example: What is the maximum number of points scored by each player, with the highest scorers first?

summary.para: Turn a query into a changefeed, an infinite stream of objects representing changes to the query's results as they occur. A changefeed may return changes to a table or an individual document (a "point" changefeed). Commands such as filter or map may be used before the changes command to transform or filter the output, and many commands that operate on sequences can be chained after changes.

example.para: Example: Subscribe to the changes on a table.
Start monitoring the changefeed in one client:
As these queries are performed in a second client, the first client would receive and print the following objects:

summary.para: Convert a ReQL geometry object to a GeoJSON object.

example.para: Example: Convert a ReQL geometry object to a GeoJSON object.

summary.para: Compute the distance between a point and another geometry object. At least one of the geometry objects specified must be a point.

example.para: Example: Compute the distance between two points on the Earth in kilometers.

summary.para: Tests whether two geometry objects intersect with one another. When applied to a sequence of geometry objects, intersects acts as a filter, returning a sequence of objects from the sequence that intersect with the argument.

example.para: Example: Is point2 within a 2000-meter circle around point1?

summary.para: Tests whether a geometry object is completely contained within another. When applied to a sequence of geometry objects, includes acts as a filter, returning a sequence of objects from the sequence that include the argument.

example.para: Example: Is point2 included within a 2000-meter circle around point1?

summary.para: Convert a Line object into a Polygon object. If the last point does not specify the same coordinates as the first point, polygon will close the polygon by connecting them.

example.para: Example: Create a line object and then convert it to a polygon.

summary.para: Use polygon2 to "punch out" a hole in polygon1. polygon2 must be completely contained within polygon1 and must have no holes itself (it must not be the output of polygonSub itself).

example.para: Example: Define a polygon with a hole punched in it.

summary.para: Return an array containing all of an object's values. values() guarantees the values will come out in the same order as keys.

example.para: Example: Get all of the values from a table row.

summary.para: Return a UUID (universally unique identifier), a string that can be used as a unique ID. If a string is passed to uuid as an argument, the UUID will be deterministic, derived from the string's SHA-1 hash.

example.para: Example: Generate a UUID.

summary.para: Return a UUID (universally unique identifier), a string that can be used as a unique ID. If a string is passed to uuid as an argument, the UUID will be deterministic, derived from the string's SHA-1 hash.

example.para: Example: Generate a UUID.

summary.para: Retrieve data from the specified URL over HTTP. The return type depends on the resultFormat option, which checks the Content-Type of the response by default.

example.para: Example: Perform an HTTP GET and store the result in a table.

summary.para: Throw a runtime error. If called with no arguments inside the second argument to default, re-throw the current error.

example.para: Example: Iron Man can't possibly have lost a battle:

summary.para: Throw a runtime error. If called with no arguments inside the second argument to default, re-throw the current error.

example.para: Example: Iron Man can't possibly have lost a battle:

summary.para: Reference a database.

example.para: Example: Explicitly specify a database for a query.

summary.para: Return all documents in a table. Other commands may be chained after table to return a subset of documents (such as get and filter) or perform further processing.

example.para: Example: Return all documents in the table 'marvel' of the default database.

summary.para: Test if two or more values are equal.

example.para: Example: See if a user's role field is set to administrator.

summary.para: Test if two or more values are not equal.

example.para: Example: See if a user's role field is not set to administrator.

summary.para: Compare values, testing if the left-hand value is less than the right-hand.

example.para: Example: Test if a player has scored less than 10 points.

summary.para: Compare values, testing if the left-hand value is less than or equal to the right-hand.

example.para: Example: Test if a player has scored 10 points or less.

summary.para: Compare values, testing if the left-hand value is greater than the right-hand.

example.para: Example: Test if a player has scored more than 10 points.

summary.para: Compare values, testing if the left-hand value is greater than or equal to the right-hand.

example.para: Example: Test if a player has scored 10 points or more.

summary.para: Compute the logical inverse (not) of an expression.

example.para: Example: Not true is false.
These evaluate to false.

summary.para: Sum two or more numbers, or concatenate two or more strings or arrays.

example.para: Example: It's as easy as 2 + 2 = 4.

summary.para: Subtract two numbers.

example.para: Example: It's as easy as 2 - 2 = 0.

summary.para: Multiply two numbers, or make a periodic array.

example.para: Example: It's as easy as 2 * 2 = 4.

summary.para: Divide two numbers.

example.para: Example: It's as easy as 2 / 2 = 1.
Example: It's as easy as 2 % 2 = 0.

summary.para: Rounds the given value down, returning the largest integer value less than or equal to the given value (the value's floor).

example.para: Example: Return the floor of 12.345.
The floor command can also be chained after an expression.

summary.para: Rounds the given value up, returning the smallest integer value greater than or equal to the given value (the value's ceiling).

example.para: Example: Return the ceiling of 12.345.
The ceil command can also be chained after an expression.

summary.para: Rounds the given value to the nearest whole integer.

example.para: Example: Round 12.345 to the nearest integer.
The round command can also be chained after an expression.

summary.para: When called with values, returns true if a sequence contains all the specified values. When called with predicate functions, returns true if for each predicate there exists at least one element of the stream where that predicate returns true.

example.para: Example: Has Iron Man ever fought Superman?

summary.para: Creates an object from a list of key-value pairs, where the keys must be strings. r.object(A, B, C, D) is equivalent to r.expr([[A, B], [C, D]]).coerce_to('OBJECT').

example.para: Example: Create a simple object.
Result:

summary.para: Produce a single value from a sequence through repeated application of a reduction function.

example.para: Example: Return the number of documents in the table posts.
A shorter way to execute this query is to use count.

summary.para: Produce a single value from a sequence through repeated application of a reduction function.

example.para: Example: Return the number of documents in the table posts.
A shorter way to execute this query is to use count.

summary.para: Apply a function to a sequence in order, maintaining state via an accumulator. The fold command returns either a single value or a new sequence.

example.para: Example: Concatenate words from a list.
(This example could be implemented with reduce, but fold will preserve the order when words is a RethinkDB table or other stream, which is not guaranteed with reduce.)

summary.para: Apply a function to a sequence in order, maintaining state via an accumulator. The fold command returns either a single value or a new sequence.

summary.para: Transform each element of one or more sequences by applying a mapping function to them. If map is run with two or more sequences, it will iterate for as many items as there are in the shortest sequence.

example.para: Example: Return the first five squares.

summary.para: Create a database. A RethinkDB database is a collection of tables, similar to relational databases.

example.para: Example: Create a database named 'superheroes'.

summary.para: Drop a database. The database, all its tables, and corresponding data will be deleted.

example.para: Example: Drop a database named 'superheroes'.

summary.para: List all database names in the system. The result is a list of strings.

example.para: Example: List all databases.

summary.para: Create a table. A RethinkDB table is a collection of JSON documents.

example.para: Example: Create a table named 'dc_universe' with the default settings.

summary.para: Drop a table from a database. The table and all its data will be deleted.

example.para: Example: Drop a table named 'dc_universe'.

summary.para: List all table names in a database. The result is a list of strings.

example.para: Example: List all tables of the 'test' database.

summary.para: Grant or deny access permissions for a user account, globally or on a per-database or per-table basis.

example.para: Example: Grant the chatapp user account read and write permissions on the users database.

summary.para: Perform a branching conditional equivalent to if-then-else.

The branch command takes 2n+1 arguments: pairs of conditional expressions and commands to be executed if the conditionals return any value but false or null (i.e., "truthy" values), with a final "else" command to be evaluated if all of the conditionals are false or null.

example.para: Example: Test the value of x.

summary.para: Create a time object based on an ISO 8601 date-time string (e.g. '2013-01-01T01:01:01+00:00'). RethinkDB supports all valid ISO 8601 formats except for week dates. Read more about the ISO 8601 format at Wikipedia.

example.para: Example: Update the time of John's birth.

summary.para: Create a time object based on seconds since epoch. The first argument is a double and will be rounded to three decimal places (millisecond-precision).

example.para: Example: Update the birthdate of the user "John" to November 3rd, 1986.

summary.para: Return a time object representing the current time in UTC. The command now() is computed once when the server receives the query, so multiple instances of r.now() will always return the same time inside a query.

example.para: Example: Add a new user with the time at which he subscribed.

summary.para: Create a time object for a specific time.

example.para: Example: Update the birthdate of the user "John" to November 3rd, 1986 UTC.

summary.para: Create a time object for a specific time.

summary.para: Replace an object in a field instead of merging it with an existing object in a merge or update operation. Using literal with no arguments in a merge or update operation will remove the corresponding field.

summary.para: Sums all the elements of a sequence. If called with a field name, sums all the values of that field in the sequence, skipping elements of the sequence that lack that field. If called with a function, calls that function on every element of the sequence and sums the results, skipping elements of the sequence where that function returns null or a non-existence error.

example.para: Example: What's 3 + 5 + 7?

example.para: Example: What's the average of 3, 5, and 7?

summary.para: r.args is a special term that's used to splice an array of arguments into another term. This is useful when you want to call a variadic term such as getAll with a set of arguments produced at runtime.

example.para: Example: Get Alice and Bob from the table people.

summary.para: Encapsulate binary data within a query.

example.para: Example: Save an avatar image to a existing user record.

summary.para: Convert a GeoJSON object to a ReQL geometry object.

example.para: Example: Convert a GeoJSON object to a ReQL geometry object.

summary.para: Construct a geometry object of type Point. The point is specified by two floating point numbers, the longitude (-180 to 180) and latitude (-90 to 90) of the point on a perfect sphere. See Geospatial support for more information on ReQL's coordinate system.

example.para: Example: Define a point.

summary.para: Construct a geometry object of type Line. The line can be specified in one of two ways:

ul.li: Two or more two-item arrays, specifying latitude and longitude numbers of the line's vertices;
Two or more Point objects specifying the line's vertices.

example.para: Example: Define a line.

summary.para: Construct a geometry object of type Polygon. The Polygon can be specified in one of two ways:

ul.li: Three or more two-item arrays, specifying latitude and longitude numbers of the polygon's vertices;
Three or more Point objects specifying the polygon's vertices.

example.para: Example: Define a polygon.

summary.para: Compute the distance between a point and another geometry object. At least one of the geometry objects specified must be a point.

example.para: Example: Compute the distance between two points on the Earth in kilometers.

summary.para: Tests whether two geometry objects intersect with one another. When applied to a sequence of geometry objects, intersects acts as a filter, returning a sequence of objects from the sequence that intersect with the argument.

example.para: Example: Is point2 within a 2000-meter circle around point1?

summary.para: Construct a circular line or polygon. A circle in RethinkDB is a polygon or line approximating a circle of a given radius around a given center, consisting of a specified number of vertices (default 32).

example.para: Example: Define a circle.

summary.para: Construct a circular line or polygon. A circle in RethinkDB is a polygon or line approximating a circle of a given radius around a given center, consisting of a specified number of vertices (default 32).

example.para: Example: Define a circle.

summary.para: Construct a circular line or polygon. A circle in RethinkDB is a polygon or line approximating a circle of a given radius around a given center, consisting of a specified number of vertices (default 32).

example.para: Example: Define a circle.

example.para: Example: It's as easy as 2 + 2 = 4.

summary.para: Averages all the elements of a sequence. If called with a field name, averages all the values of that field in the sequence, skipping elements of the sequence that lack that field. If called with a function, calls that function on every element of the sequence and averages the results, skipping elements of the sequence where that function returns null or a non-existence error.

example.para: Example: What's the average of 3, 5, and 7?

summary.para: Averages all the elements of a sequence. If called with a field name, averages all the values of that field in the sequence, skipping elements of the sequence that lack that field. If called with a function, calls that function on every element of the sequence and averages the results, skipping elements of the sequence where that function returns null or a non-existence error.

example.para: Example: What's the average of 3, 5, and 7?

summary.para: Get all documents between two keys. Accepts three optional arguments: index, leftBound, and rightBound. If index is set to the name of a secondary index, between will return all documents where that index's value is in the specified range (it uses the primary key by default). leftBound or rightBound may be set to open or closed to indicate whether or not to include that endpoint of the range (by default, leftBound is closed and rightBound is open).

example.para: Example: Find all users with primary key >= 10 and < 20 (a normal half-open interval).

summary.para: Perform a branching conditional equivalent to if-then-else.

The branch command takes 2n+1 arguments: pairs of conditional expressions and commands to be executed if the conditionals return any value but false or null (i.e., "truthy" values), with a final "else" command to be evaluated if all of the conditionals are false or null.

example.para: Example: Test the value of x.

summary.para: Turn a query into a changefeed, an infinite stream of objects representing changes to the query's results as they occur. A changefeed may return changes to a table or an individual document (a "point" changefeed). Commands such as filter or map may be used before the changes command to transform or filter the output, and many commands that operate on sequences can be chained after changes.

example.para: Example: Subscribe to the changes on a table.

summary.para: Provide a default value in case of non-existence errors. The default command evaluates its first argument (the value it's chained to). If that argument returns null or a non-existence error is thrown in evaluation, then default returns its second argument. The second argument is usually a default value, but it can be a function that returns a value.

example.para: Example: Retrieve the titles and authors of the table posts. In the case where the author field is missing or null, we want to retrieve the string Anonymous.

summary.para: Provide a default value in case of non-existence errors. The default command evaluates its first argument (the value it's chained to). If that argument returns null or a non-existence error is thrown in evaluation, then default returns its second argument. The second argument is usually a default value, but it can be a function that returns a value.

example.para: Example: Retrieve the titles and authors of the table posts. In the case where the author field is missing or null, we want to retrieve the string Anonymous.

summary.para: Provide a default value in case of non-existence errors. The default command evaluates its first argument (the value it's chained to). If that argument returns null or a non-existence error is thrown in evaluation, then default returns its second argument. The second argument is usually a default value, but it can be a function that returns a value.

example.para: Example: Retrieve the titles and authors of the table posts. In the case where the author field is missing or null, we want to retrieve the string Anonymous.

summary.para: Join tables using a field or function on the left-hand sequence matching primary keys or secondary indexes on the right-hand table. eqJoin is more efficient than other ReQL join types, and operates much faster. Documents in the result set consist of pairs of left-hand and right-hand documents, matched when the field on the left-hand side exists and is non-null and an entry with that field's value exists in the specified index on the right-hand side.

summary.para: Rename an existing secondary index on a table. If the optional argument overwrite is specified as true, a previously existing index with the new name will be deleted and the index will be renamed. If overwrite is false (the default) an error will be raised if the new index name already exists.

summary.para: Matches against a regular expression. If there is a match, returns an object with the fields:

ul.li: str: The matched string
start: The matched string's start
end: The matched string's end
groups: The capture groups defined with parentheses

summary.para: If no match is found, returns null.

example.para: Example: Get all users whose name starts with "A". Because null evaluates to false in filter, you can just use the result of match for the predicate.

summary.para: Merge two or more objects together to construct a new object with properties from all. When there is a conflict between field names, preference is given to fields in the rightmost object in the argument list. merge also accepts a subquery function that returns an object, which will be used similarly to a map function.

example.para: Example: Equip Thor for battle.

member.summary: Get the nth element of a sequence, counting from zero. If the argument is negative, count from the last element.

summary.para: Returns a left outer join of two sequences. The returned sequence represents a union of the left-hand sequence and the right-hand sequence: all documents in the left-hand sequence will be returned, each matched with a document in the right-hand sequence if one satisfies the predicate condition. In most cases, you will want to follow the join with zip to combine the left and right results.

example.para: Example: Return a list of all Marvel heroes, paired with any DC heroes who could beat them in a fight.
(Compare this to an innerJoin with the same inputs and predicate, which would return a list only of the matchups in which the DC hero has the higher strength.)

summary.para: Splits a string into substrings. Splits on whitespace when called with no arguments. When called with a separator, splits on that separator. When called with a separator and a maximum number of splits, splits on that separator at most max_splits times. (Can be called with null as the separator if you want to split on whitespace while still specifying max_splits.)

example.para: Example: Split on whitespace.
Result:

summary.para: Sums all the elements of a sequence. If called with a field name, sums all the values of that field in the sequence, skipping elements of the sequence that lack that field. If called with a function, calls that function on every element of the sequence and sums the results, skipping elements of the sequence where that function returns null or a non-existence error.

example.para: Example: What's 3 + 5 + 7?

summary.para: sync ensures that writes on a given table are written to permanent storage. Queries that specify soft durability ({durability: 'soft'}) do not give such guarantees, so sync can be used to ensure the state of these queries. A call to sync does not return until all previous writes to the table are persisted.

example.para: Example: After having updated multiple heroes with soft durability, we now want to wait until these changes are persisted.

summary.para: Create a new secondary index on a table. Secondary indexes improve the speed of many read queries at the slight cost of increased storage space and decreased write performance. For more information about secondary indexes, read the article "Using secondary indexes in RethinkDB."

summary.para: Rename an existing secondary index on a table. If the optional argument overwrite is specified as true, a previously existing index with the new name will be deleted and the index will be renamed. If overwrite is false (the default) an error will be raised if the new index name already exists.

example.para: Example: Rename an index on the comments table.

summary.para: Get all documents where the given geometry object intersects the geometry object of the requested geospatial index.

summary.para: Get all documents where the specified geospatial index is within a certain distance of the specified point (default 100 kilometers).

example.para: Example: Return a list of enemy hideouts within 5000 meters of the secret base.

summary.para: Takes a grouped stream or grouped data and turns it into an array of objects representing the groups. Any commands chained after ungroup will operate on this array, rather than operating on each group individually. This is useful if you want to e.g. order the groups by the value of their reduction.

example.para: Example: What is the maximum number of points scored by each player, with the highest scorers first?

member.name: T:RethinkDb.Driver.Model.ChangeState
member.summary: Change feed states

member.name: F:RethinkDb.Driver.Model.ChangeState.Initializing
member.summary: {state: 'initializing'} indicates the following documents represent initial values on the feed rather than changes. This will be the first document of a feed that returns initial values.

member.name: F:RethinkDb.Driver.Model.ChangeState.Ready
member.summary: {state: 'ready'} indicates the following documents represent changes. This will be the first document of a feed that does not return initial values; otherwise, it will indicate the initial values have all been sent.

member.name: T:RethinkDb.Driver.Model.ChangeType
member.summary: If the change feed query contains the include_types opt arg, every result on a changefeed will include a type field with a string that indicates the kind of change the result represents: add, remove, change, initial, uninitial, state.

member.summary: Document was added.

member.name: F:RethinkDb.Driver.Model.ChangeType.Remove
member.summary: Document was removed

member.name: F:RethinkDb.Driver.Model.ChangeType.Change
member.summary: Document was changed.

member.name: F:RethinkDb.Driver.Model.ChangeType.Initial
member.summary: Initial document.

member.name: F:RethinkDb.Driver.Model.ChangeType.Uninitial
member.summary: If an initial result for a document has been sent and a change is made to that document that would move it to the unsent part of the result set (e.g., a changefeed monitors the top 100 posters, the first 50 have been sent, and poster 48 has become poster 52), an 'uninitial' notification will be sent, with an old_val field but no new_val field.

member.summary: If include_states = true optional argument was specified, the changefeed stream will include special status documents consisting of the state indicating a change in the feeds state. These states can occur at any point in the feed between the notifications. If includeStates = false (the default), the state status will not be set. See .

The boolean value should be considered a "rough" estimate of the availability of a node in the pool. This indicator may lag behind as it does not check the exact state of every node's TCP socket.

member.summary: Starts the connection pool.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Net.Clustering.ConnectionPool.Discoverer
member.summary: This thread is in charge of discovering new hosts via rethinkdb system table change feed. If a new host is found it is added to the host pool.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Net.Clustering.ConnectionPool.MaybeAddNewHost(RethinkDb.Driver.Net.Clustering.Server)
member.summary: Called by the discoverer thread when a new server has been added (or comes back online). This method will determine if AddHost is needed. We only have monotonically increasing hosts to prevent unnecessary locking on the host list array.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Net.Clustering.ConnectionPool.Supervisor
member.summary: This thread is mainly in charge of supervising the connections. The supervisor will kick off a worker to try to reconnect connections that are due for reconnecting. It also scans though the host list looking for connections that are not dead but have errors and attempts to reset them.

member.name: T:RethinkDb.Driver.Net.Clustering.EpsilonGreedyHostPool
member.summary:
Epsilon Greedy is an algorithm that allows HostPool not only to track failure state, but also to learn about "better" options in terms of speed, and to pick from available hosts based on how well they perform. This gives a weighted request rate to better performing hosts, while still distributing requests to all hosts (proportionate to their performance).
A good overview of Epsilon Greedy is here http://stevehanov.ca/blog/index.php?id=132
To compute the weighting scores, we perform a weighted average of recent response times, over the course of `decayDuration`. decayDuration may be set to null to use the default value of 5 minutes We then use the supplied EpsilonValueCalculator to calculate a score from that weighted average response time.

member.name: F:RethinkDb.Driver.Net.Clustering.EpsilonGreedyHostPool.InitialEpsilon
member.summary: Initial epsilon value.

member.name: F:RethinkDb.Driver.Net.Clustering.EpsilonGreedyHostPool.MinEpsilon
member.summary: The steady state percentage of time to explore

member.name: F:RethinkDb.Driver.Net.Clustering.EpsilonGreedyHostPool.EpsilonDecay
member.summary: The decay exploration rate.

member.name: F:RethinkDb.Driver.Net.Clustering.EpsilonGreedyHostPool.EpsilonBuckets
member.summary: Number of bucket slot measurements

member.name: F:RethinkDb.Driver.Net.Clustering.EpsilonGreedyHostPool.epsilon
member.summary: Epsilon threshold that controls exploration. If a random double is less than < (or below) epsilon, then an round-robin exploration is performed. IE: Higher the epsilon, the more chances for exploration of other hosts. In the long run, epsilon will EpsilonDecay on each exploration until reaching MinEpsilon. Additionally, in the long run, exploration will only take place MinEpsilon % of the time.

member.name: P:RethinkDb.Driver.Net.Clustering.EpsilonGreedyHostPool.Random
member.summary: Random value generator.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Net.Clustering.EpsilonGreedyHostPool.#ctor(System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan},System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan},System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan},RethinkDb.Driver.Net.Clustering.EpsilonValueCalculator,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Construct an Epsilon Greedy HostPool
Epsilon Greedy is an algorithm that allows HostPool not only to track failure state, but also to learn about "better" options in terms of speed, and to pick from available hosts based on how well they perform. This gives a weighted request rate to better performing hosts, while still distributing requests to all hosts (proportionate to their performance).
A good overview of Epsilon Greedy is here http://stevehanov.ca/blog/index.php?id=132
To compute the weighting scores, we perform a weighted average of recent response times, over the course of `decayDuration`. decayDuration may be set to null to use the default value of 5 minutes We then use the supplied EpsilonValueCalculator to calculate a score from that weighted average response time.
member.param: The initial retry delay when a host goes down. Default, null, is 30 seconds.
The maximum retry delay when a host goes down. Default, null, is 15 minutes.

The amount of time to cycle through all EpsilonBuckets (0...120). This decay duration is divided by EpsilonBuckets (default: 5 min / 120 buckets = 2.5 seconds per bucket). IE: The average will be taken every decayDuration/EpsilonBuckets seconds.
Given the weighted average among EpsilonBuckets slot measurements, calculate the host's EpsilonValue using EpsilonCalculators.Linear/Logarithmic/Polynomial(exponent)
Automatically starts the decay timer. If false, you need to call StartDecayTimer manually for epsilon values to be calculated correctly.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Net.Clustering.EpsilonGreedyHostPool.#ctor(System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan},RethinkDb.Driver.Net.Clustering.EpsilonValueCalculator,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Construct an Epsilon Greedy HostPool
Epsilon Greedy is an algorithm that allows HostPool not only to track failure state, but also to learn about "better" options in terms of speed, and to pick from available hosts based on how well they perform. This gives a weighted request rate to better performing hosts, while still distributing requests to all hosts (proportionate to their performance).
A good overview of Epsilon Greedy is here http://stevehanov.ca/blog/index.php?id=132
To compute the weighting scores, we perform a weighted average of recent response times, over the course of `decayDuration`. decayDuration may be set to null to use the default value of 5 minutes We then use the supplied EpsilonValueCalculator to calculate a score from that weighted average response time.
member.param: The amount of time to cycle though all EpsilonBuckets (0...120). This decay duration is divided by EpsilonBuckets (default: 5 min / 120 buckets = 2.5 seconds per bucket). IE: The average will be taken every decayDuration/EpsilonBuckets seconds.
Given the weighted average among EpsilonBuckets slot measurements, calculate the host's EpsilonValue using EpsilonCalculators.Linear/Logarithmic/Polynomial(exponent)
Automatically starts the decay timer. If false, you need to call StartDecayTimer manually for epsilon values to be calculated correctly.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Net.Clustering.EpsilonGreedyHostPool.SetEpsilon(System.Single)
member.summary: Epsilon threshold that controls exploration. If a random double is less than < (or below) epsilon, then an round-robin exploration is performed. IE: Higher the epsilon, the more chances for exploration of other hosts. In the long run, epsilon will EpsilonDecay on each exploration to MinEpsilon.

member.summary: If the autoStartDecayTimer was false, you need to start the decay timer manually using this method.

member.name: T:RethinkDb.Driver.Net.Clustering.EpsilonValueCalculator
member.summary: Classes implementing this interface are used to convert the average response time for a host into a score that can be used to weight hosts in the epsilon greedy hostpool. Lower response times should yield higher scores (we want to select the faster hosts more often) The default LinearEpsilonValueCalculator just uses the reciprocal of the response time. In practice, any decreasing function from the positive reals to the positive reals should work.

member.name: T:RethinkDb.Driver.Net.Clustering.RoundRobinHostPool
member.summary: Create a new RoundRobin host pool. Each host is used in a round robin strategy when processing each query.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Net.Clustering.RoundRobinHostPool.#ctor(System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan},System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan})
member.summary: Create a new RoundRobin host pool. Each host is used in a round robin strategy when processing each query. When a host goes down, the supervisor will wait retryDelayInitial timespan before trying again. If the reconnect fails, the retry delay is doubled. Doubling of the retry is stopped at once the retry delay is greater than retryDelayMax; thereafter, every subsequent retry is retryDelayMax. The retryDelayInitial is 30 seconds, and retryDelayMax is 15 minutes.
member.param: The initial retry delay when a host goes down. Default, null, is 30 seconds.
The maximum retry delay when a host goes down. Default, null, is 15 minutes.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Net.Clustering.RoundRobinHostPool.#ctor
member.summary: Create a new RoundRobin host pool. Each host is used in a round robin strategy when processing each query. When a host goes down, the supervisor will wait retryDelayInitial timespan before trying again. If the reconnect fails, the retry delay is doubled. Doubling of the retry is stopped at once the retry delay is greater than retryDelayMax; thereafter, every subsequent retry is retryDelayMax. The retryDelayInitial is 30 seconds, and retryDelayMax is 15 minutes.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Net.Cursor`1.MoveNext
member.summary: Advances the cursor to the next item. This is a blocking operation if there are no buffered items to advance on and a response from the server is needed.

member.name: M:RethinkDb.Driver.Net.Cursor`1.MoveNextAsync(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Asynchronously advances the cursor to the next item.

param.name: cancelToken
param.para: Used to cancel the advancement of the next item if it takes too long.
The has no effect if the cursor still has buffered items to draw from. Cancellation pertains to the wait on an outstanding network request that is taking too long.
If the is canceled before is called, is thrown immediately before any operation begins.

Additionally, cancellation is a safe operation. When a is thrown, the exception will not disrupt the ordering of cursor items. Cancellation only pertains to the semantic *wait* on a pending network request. Cancellation will not cancel an already in-progress network request for more items. Therefore, a will not disrupt the success of future precedent calls to . Network requests will still arrive in order at some later time.

exception.para: Thrown when is canceled before is called.
Thrown when there are no buffered items to draw from and operation requires waiting on a response from the server.
When is thrown the exception will not disrupt the ordering of items. Any non-canceled precedent calls to from an antecedent canceled will advance the cursor normally and maintain ordering of items.
